Title: Invertibility of compact operators in infinite-dimensional Banach spaces
Content: Let $X$ be an infinite-dimensional Banach space, and $T$ a compact operator from $X$ to $X$. Why must $0$ then be a spectral value for $T$? I believe this is equivalent to saying that $T$ is not bijective, but I am not sure how to show that injectivity implies the absence of surjectivity and the other way around (or if this is even the right way to approach the problem).
AcceptedAnswer: You are correct that it is the same as saying that $T$ is not bijective, because it follows from the open mapping theorem that a bounded operator on a Banach space has a bounded inverse if it is bijective.  However, more straightforward answers for your question can be given without explicitly thinking in these terms. You can show that if $T$ is compact and $S$ is bounded, then $ST$ is compact.  If $T$ were invertible, this would imply that $I=T^{-1}T$ is compact.  This in turn translates to saying that the closed unit ball of $X$ is compact.  One way to see that this is impossible in the infinite dimensional case is implicit in this question .  There is an infinite sequence of points in the unit ball whose pairwise distances are bounded below, no subsequence of which is Cauchy. Compact operators on infinite dimensional spaces can be injective, but they can never be surjective.  The closed subspaces of the range of a compact operator are finite dimensional. Also, what Qiaochu said in his comment above.

First, I need to recall some functional analysis concepts. Compact operators on infinite-dimensional spaces have some special properties. For instance, the spectrum of a compact operator includes 0, and all non-zero elements of the spectrum are eigenvalues with finite multiplicity. But the key point here is that in infinite dimensions, a compact operator cannot be invertible. That's because the image of the unit ball under a compact operator is relatively compact, and in infinite-dimensional spaces, the unit ball isn't compact. So if T were invertible, its inverse would map the compact set back to the unit ball, which can't happen since the inverse would be bounded, preserving compactness, but the unit ball isn't compact in infinite dimensions. Therefore, 0 must be in the spectrum, meaning T isn't invertible.

Now, the user is relating this to bijectivity. In Banach spaces, a bounded operator that is bijective has a bounded inverse due to the Open Mapping Theorem. So if T is compact and bijective, then T^{-1} would be bounded. But as above, this would lead to a contradiction because T being compact and invertible would imply the unit ball is compact. Hence, T can't be bijective. Therefore, if T is injective, it can't be surjective, and if it's surjective, it can't be injective. This shows that 0 is in the spectrum because the spectrum includes all λ where T - λI isn't invertible. Since T isn't invertible (as it can't be bijective), 0 is a spectral value.
